title: Who is the best guitarist between Eddie Van Halen, Jimi Hendrix and Eric Clapton? - Quora

response.answer_text: “My chops are not as fast... [but] I just learned more on what was in my mind than what was in my chops. I learned a long time ago that one note can go a long way if it's the right one, and it will probably whip the guy with twenty notes.” – Les Paul “Differences of opinion... [are] part of collaborating with another human being. But music is not a competitive thing. I don't want to deal with someone who's in competition with me, I want to work together and make music.” – Edward Van Halen “I like to play with people who can play simple and are not threatened by other musicians thinking they can't play. And that eliminates 99 percent of the musicians.” --Neil Young There’s something in me that resists the whole competitive thing, who’s better, who’s faster, who’s on top. (Maybe that’s because I’m surrounded by amazing musicians in my hometown(?)) A lot of it comes down to taste, and more importantly, to what really resonates with you, as a listener, and as a musician. What kind of a guitarist was B.B. King? Not flashy, certainly. Not fast, not a rule-breaker. But he could say more with one note than Yngwie Malmsteen could say with a hundred (and no, I’m not putting down Yngwie Malmsteen! I’m simply pointing out that virtuosity isn’t everything). B.B. King lived the blues, and that experience informed every note he played. Similarly, David Gilmour isn’t a flashy player either, but he knows how to communicate, through his playing, which is something I really respect. In short, it’s not how you play, but what you’re saying with what you play. If you’re shredding up a storm but not saying anything of consequence, people may think, “wow, that was flashy!” but an hour later they probably won’t remember a damn note. I respect Clapton a lot. I respect Eddie a lot (RIP!)… But, I will end with this: of all the guitarists that were hot tickets when I was a kid growing up (Clapton, Townshend, Mayall, Page, Zappa, and many others (all of whom I love, BTW)) it was Hendrix that inspired me to pick up a guitar, and learn to play it.

First of all, Eric Clapton is not even remotely part of the argument. Jimi Hendrix (as a lefty) had to re-string a guitar and teach himself how to play it because there were no left-handed guitars at that time. Eddie (God Bless his Soul) was an AMAZING guitarist. Long ago, I thought he was the greatest, BUT I watched a video with David Lee Roth that completely changed my mind. While he was in no way trying to criticize Eddie’s talents, he brought to light the fact that when Van Halen was on the rise, they began using equipment that would allow them to take an enormous amount of “tracks.” So, they could record the song as a band on 8 tracks, then let Eddie record solos on the remaining 24 tracks, and then splice them together to make unheard-of guitar solos that could never be duplicated. Then, Eddie went home and tried to figure out how he could splice it all together for the live performances. I love Eddie. But he doesn’t hold a candle to Hendrix. Unfortunately, I can’t find the video to link it to due to the overwhelming videos being posted in the last few days, but it is out there on youtube. RIP Eddie.
